com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.locking.consistentkey

Class ConsistentKeyLockTransaction

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.locking.consistentkey.ConsistentKeyLockTransaction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    StoreTransaction, TransactionHandle

    public class ConsistentKeyLockTransaction
extends Object
implements StoreTransaction
    A StoreTransaction that supports locking via LocalLockMediator and writing and reading lock records in a ConsistentKeyLockStore.

    This class is not safe for concurrent use by multiple threads. Multithreaded access must be prevented or externally synchronized.

      • flush

        public void flush()
           throws StorageException
        Description copied from interface: TransactionHandle
        Forces all buffered writes to be sent to underlying storage. It is not necessary or meaningful to call this method on a TransactionHandle instance after calling TransactionHandle.commit() or TransactionHandle.rollback() on the instance.
        Specified by:

      • isMutationStarted

        public boolean isMutationStarted()
        Tells whether this transaction has been used in a ConsistentKeyLockStore.mutate(StaticBuffer, List, List, StoreTransaction) call. When this returns true, the transaction is no longer allowed in calls to ConsistentKeyLockStore.acquireLock(StaticBuffer, StaticBuffer, StaticBuffer, StoreTransaction).
        Returns:
        False until ConsistentKeyLockStore.mutate(StaticBuffer, List, List, StoreTransaction) is called on this transaction instance. Returns true forever after.

      • mutationStarted

        public void mutationStarted()
        Signals the transaction that it has been used in a call to ConsistentKeyLockStore.mutate(StaticBuffer, List, List, StoreTransaction) . This transaction can't be used in subsequent calls to ConsistentKeyLockStore.acquireLock(StaticBuffer, StaticBuffer, StaticBuffer, StoreTransaction) .

        Calling this method at the appropriate time is handled automatically by ConsistentKeyLockStore. Titan users don't need to call this method by hand.

      • writeBlindLockClaim

        public void writeBlindLockClaim(ConsistentKeyLockStore backer,
                       StaticBuffer key,
                       StaticBuffer column,
                       StaticBuffer expectedValue)
                         throws StorageException
        Attempts to lock the supplied (key, column, expectedValue).

        Conflicts with locks held by other transactions within the process are detected using LocalLockMediator before this method returns. Such conflicts generate LockingExceptions.

        Conflicts with locks held by transactions in other processes will not be detected before this method returns. We optimistically write a lock claim to backer's lockStore, but whether the claim takes precedence and the lock succeeded won't be checked until verifyAllLockClaims().

        Unless there's an StorageException-worthy problem communicating with backer's lockStore, such as failure to connect or exceptionally high write latency, this method concludes by appending a LockClaim to its #lockClaims hash set and then returns. The LockClaim lets #verifyAllLockClaims() find and check this lock attempt when called.

        Therefore, if this method returns instead of throwing an exception, we know the following:

        • The attempted lock conflicts with no other transactions in the process
        • Whether the attempted lock conflicts with transactions in remote processes is uncertain until #verifyAllLockClaims() returns
        Parameters:
        backer - the store containing lock data and configuration parameters
        key - the key to lock
        column - the column to lock
        expectedValue - the value which must be present at (key, column) in backer's dataStore when #verifyAllLockClaims() is called later
        Throws:
        LockingException
        StorageException

      • verifyAllLockClaims

        public void verifyAllLockClaims()
                         throws StorageException
        For each object in the lockClaims set, this method verifies both of the following conditions:
        1. that no transaction in another Titan process holds the lock
        2. that the claim's expectedValue, as provided in the earlier call to writeBlindLockClaim(), matches the actual value in the data store

        If this method reads lockStore and finds that a transaction in a different Titan process holds one of our claimed locks, then this method throws a LockingException and the transaction's lock attempts should be considered failed.

        If this method finds a mismatch between a claim's expected value and actual value, then it will also throw a LockingException.

        If this method returns without throwing an exception, then the transaction holds all locks it previously requested via writeBlindLockClaim() and the expectedValue associated with each transaction matches the actual values seen in the dataStore.

        Throws:
        StorageException - if there's an unexpected problem talking to backer's dataStore or lockStore
        LockingException - if a lock claim has failed
